review.title: Quantum Mechanical Approach to Modelling Reliability of Sensor Reports
review.abstract: Dempster-Shafer evidence theory is wildly applied in multi-sensor data fusion. However, lots of uncertainty and interference exist in practical situation, especially in the battle field. It is still an open issue to model the reliability of sensor reports. Many methods are proposed based on the relationship among collected data. In this letter, we proposed a quantum mechanical approach to evaluate the reliability of sensor reports, which is based on the properties of a sensor itself. The proposed method is used to modify the combining of evidences.

metadata.title: Combining Evidences Based on Quantum Mechanical Approach

sections.text: In this letter, we propose a quantum mechanical approach to evaluate the reliability of sensor reports based on the properties of a sensor itself, and the proposed method is used to modify the combination of evidence. Keywords: Dempster Shafer Evidence Theory, Multi-Sensor Data Fusion, Quantum Mechanics, Sensor Report Reliability. Author at: School of Electronics and Information, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi'an, Shaanxi 710072, China. Tel.: + 8613363912605. Email address: jiangwen @ nwpu.edu.cn, jiwenpaper @ mail.com.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Data fusion has been extensively studied in recent decades, especially its military applications. Multi-sensor data fusion (MSDF) technology is playing an increasingly important role in combat demand. How to merge sensor data is still an open question [1-4]. Due to its strong ability to handle uncertain information, DS evidence theory is widely used in MSDF [5-8]. However, dealing with conflicts is crucial in the complex practical situation. The information provided by a sensor report is likely to be disturbed and false. In this case, there may be a strong conflict between the evidence and lead to a false fusion result. Dealing with conflicts is crucial for data fusion [9-12]. To resolve it, many approaches have been proposed [13-15]. In order to deal with conflicting information, most previous methods deal with evidence based on the relationship between the data collected by sensors, leading to a false fusion result [13-15]. However, this letter suggests that a quantum result itself is a method [19].

sections.heading: 3. Quantum mechanical modelling of the sensor reliability in data
sections.text: In order to achieve a more reasonable fusion, we propose a method based on quantum mechanics to determine the confidence coefficient curve of radar sensor reports. We assume that the reliability of sensor reports refers to the distance between object and sensor in some degrees. The signal of the object is received by radars. Transmission power of the object is Pt, the antenna gain of the object is Gt, the antenna gain of the reconnaissance radar is Gr, the distance between object and radar is called x. The signal strength of the radar is: Pr = PtGtG.2 (6), where the antenna gain of the reconnaissance radar is Gr, the distance between object and radar is called x.

sections.text: In this section, a numerical example is illustrated to show the effectiveness of our method. In a target detection system, five radar sensors have collected five BOEs, which are represented as follows: (R1, m1) = ([{A}, 0.6], [{B}, 0.15], [{A, C}, 0.25] (R2, m2) = ({{A}, 0.5], [{B}, 0.3], [{C}, 0.2]) (R3, m3) = ([{B}, 0.95], [{C}, 0.05]) (R4, m4) = ({{A}, 0.55], [{B}, 0.25], [{A, C}, 0.2]) (R5, m5) = ([{A}, 0.6], [{B}, 0.3], [B, C}, 0.1]). sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In summary, we propose a new method for modelling the reliability of sensor reports. In contrast to previous methods, we focus on the characteristics of a sensor itself. A radar sensor's confidence coefficient curve is determined by solving a quasi-time independent Schrödinger equation, which is applied when combining evidence, and the result demonstrates the efficiency of our method.
